<a id="class_Vector4i"></a>

# Vector4i

A 4D vector using integer coordinates.

<!-- classref-introduction-group -->

## Description

A 4-element structure that can be used to represent 4D grid coordinates or any other quadruplet of integers.

It uses integer coordinates and is therefore preferable to [Vector4](class_vector4.md) when exact precision is required. Note that the values are limited to 32 bits, and unlike [Vector4](class_vector4.md) this cannot be configured with an engine build option. Use [int](class_int.md) or [PackedInt64Array](class_packedint64array.md) if 64-bit values are needed.

\ **Note:** In a boolean context, a Vector4i will evaluate to ``false`` if it's equal to ``Vector4i(0, 0, 0, 0)``. Otherwise, a Vector4i will always evaluate to ``true``.

<!-- classref-reftable-group -->

## Constants

<a id="class_Vector4i_constant_ZERO"></a>

<!-- classref-constant -->

**ZERO** = `Vector4i(0, 0, 0, 0)` [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_constant_ZERO)

Zero vector, a vector with all components set to ``0``.

<a id="class_Vector4i_constant_ONE"></a>

<!-- classref-constant -->

**ONE** = `Vector4i(1, 1, 1, 1)` [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_constant_ONE)

One vector, a vector with all components set to ``1``.

<a id="class_Vector4i_constant_MIN"></a>

<!-- classref-constant -->

**MIN** = `Vector4i(-2147483648, -2147483648, -2147483648, -2147483648)` [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_constant_MIN)

Min vector, a vector with all components equal to ``INT32_MIN``. Can be used as a negative integer equivalent of [Vector4.INF](class_vector4.md#class_Vector4_constant_INF).

<a id="class_Vector4i_constant_MAX"></a>

<!-- classref-constant -->

**MAX** = `Vector4i(2147483647, 2147483647, 2147483647, 2147483647)` [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_constant_MAX)

Max vector, a vector with all components equal to ``INT32_MAX``. Can be used as an integer equivalent of [Vector4.INF](class_vector4.md#class_Vector4_constant_INF).

## Constructor Descriptions

<a id="class_Vector4i_constructor_Vector4i"></a>

<!-- classref-constructor -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **Vector4i**\ (\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_constructor_Vector4i)

Constructs a default-initialized **Vector4i** with all components set to ``0``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<!-- classref-constructor -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **Vector4i**\ (\ from\: [Vector4i](class_vector4i.md)\ )

Constructs a **Vector4i** as a copy of the given **Vector4i**.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<!-- classref-constructor -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **Vector4i**\ (\ from\: [Vector4](class_vector4.md)\ )

Constructs a new **Vector4i** from the given [Vector4](class_vector4.md) by truncating components' fractional parts (rounding towards zero). For a different behavior consider passing the result of [Vector4.ceil()](class_vector4.md#class_Vector4_method_ceil), [Vector4.floor()](class_vector4.md#class_Vector4_method_floor) or [Vector4.round()](class_vector4.md#class_Vector4_method_round) to this constructor instead.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<!-- classref-constructor -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **Vector4i**\ (\ x\: [int](class_int.md), y\: [int](class_int.md), z\: [int](class_int.md), w\: [int](class_int.md)\ )

Returns a **Vector4i** with the given components.

<hr class="classref-section-separator">

<!-- classref-descriptions-group -->

## Method Descriptions

<a id="class_Vector4i_method_abs"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **abs**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_method_abs)

Returns a new vector with all components in absolute values (i.e. positive).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_method_clamp"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **clamp**\ (\ min\: [Vector4i](class_vector4i.md), max\: [Vector4i](class_vector4i.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_method_clamp)

Returns a new vector with all components clamped between the components of `min` and `max`, by running [@GlobalScope.clamp()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_clamp) on each component.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_method_clampi"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **clampi**\ (\ min\: [int](class_int.md), max\: [int](class_int.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_method_clampi)

Returns a new vector with all components clamped between `min` and `max`, by running [@GlobalScope.clamp()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_clamp) on each component.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_method_distance_squared_to"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[int](class_int.md) **distance_squared_to**\ (\ to\: [Vector4i](class_vector4i.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_method_distance_squared_to)

Returns the squared distance between this vector and `to`.

This method runs faster than [distance_to()](class_vector4i.md#class_Vector4i_method_distance_to), so prefer it if you need to compare vectors or need the squared distance for some formula.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_method_distance_to"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[float](class_float.md) **distance_to**\ (\ to\: [Vector4i](class_vector4i.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_method_distance_to)

Returns the distance between this vector and `to`.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_method_length"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[float](class_float.md) **length**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_method_length)

Returns the length (magnitude) of this vector.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_method_length_squared"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[int](class_int.md) **length_squared**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_method_length_squared)

Returns the squared length (squared magnitude) of this vector.

This method runs faster than [length()](class_vector4i.md#class_Vector4i_method_length), so prefer it if you need to compare vectors or need the squared distance for some formula.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_method_max"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **max**\ (\ with\: [Vector4i](class_vector4i.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_method_max)

Returns the component-wise maximum of this and `with`, equivalent to ``Vector4i(maxi(x, with.x), maxi(y, with.y), maxi(z, with.z), maxi(w, with.w))``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_method_max_axis_index"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[int](class_int.md) **max_axis_index**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_method_max_axis_index)

Returns the axis of the vector's highest value. See ``AXIS_*`` constants. If all components are equal, this method returns [AXIS_X](class_vector4i.md#class_Vector4i_constant_AXIS_X).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_method_maxi"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **maxi**\ (\ with\: [int](class_int.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_method_maxi)

Returns the component-wise maximum of this and `with`, equivalent to ``Vector4i(maxi(x, with), maxi(y, with), maxi(z, with), maxi(w, with))``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_method_min"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **min**\ (\ with\: [Vector4i](class_vector4i.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_method_min)

Returns the component-wise minimum of this and `with`, equivalent to ``Vector4i(mini(x, with.x), mini(y, with.y), mini(z, with.z), mini(w, with.w))``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_method_min_axis_index"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[int](class_int.md) **min_axis_index**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_method_min_axis_index)

Returns the axis of the vector's lowest value. See ``AXIS_*`` constants. If all components are equal, this method returns [AXIS_W](class_vector4i.md#class_Vector4i_constant_AXIS_W).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_method_mini"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **mini**\ (\ with\: [int](class_int.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_method_mini)

Returns the component-wise minimum of this and `with`, equivalent to ``Vector4i(mini(x, with), mini(y, with), mini(z, with), mini(w, with))``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_method_sign"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **sign**\ (\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_method_sign)

Returns a new vector with each component set to ``1`` if it's positive, ``-1`` if it's negative, and ``0`` if it's zero. The result is identical to calling [@GlobalScope.sign()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_sign) on each component.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_method_snapped"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **snapped**\ (\ step\: [Vector4i](class_vector4i.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_method_snapped)

Returns a new vector with each component snapped to the closest multiple of the corresponding component in `step`.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_method_snappedi"></a>

<!-- classref-method -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **snappedi**\ (\ step\: [int](class_int.md)\ ) <span class="const">const</span> [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_method_snappedi)

Returns a new vector with each component snapped to the closest multiple of `step`.

<hr class="classref-section-separator">

<!-- classref-descriptions-group -->

## Operator Descriptions

<a id="class_Vector4i_operator_neq_Vector4i"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **operator !=**\ (\ right\: [Vector4i](class_vector4i.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_operator_neq_Vector4i)

Returns ``true`` if the vectors are not equal.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_operator_mod_Vector4i"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **operator %**\ (\ right\: [Vector4i](class_vector4i.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_operator_mod_Vector4i)

Gets the remainder of each component of the **Vector4i** with the components of the given **Vector4i**. This operation uses truncated division, which is often not desired as it does not work well with negative numbers. Consider using [@GlobalScope.posmod()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_posmod) instead if you want to handle negative numbers.

```
    print(Vector4i(10, -20, 30, -40) % Vector4i(7, 8, 9, 10)) # Prints (3, -4, 3, 0)
```

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_operator_mod_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **operator %**\ (\ right\: [int](class_int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_operator_mod_int)

Gets the remainder of each component of the **Vector4i** with the given [int](class_int.md). This operation uses truncated division, which is often not desired as it does not work well with negative numbers. Consider using [@GlobalScope.posmod()](class_@globalscope.md#class_@GlobalScope_method_posmod) instead if you want to handle negative numbers.

```
    print(Vector4i(10, -20, 30, -40) % 7) # Prints (3, -6, 2, -5)
```

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_operator_mul_Vector4i"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [Vector4i](class_vector4i.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_operator_mul_Vector4i)

Multiplies each component of the **Vector4i** by the components of the given **Vector4i**.

```
    print(Vector4i(10, 20, 30, 40) * Vector4i(3, 4, 5, 6)) # Prints (30, 80, 150, 240)
```

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_operator_mul_float"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_operator_mul_float)

Multiplies each component of the **Vector4i** by the given [float](class_float.md).

Returns a Vector4 value due to floating-point operations.

```
    print(Vector4i(10, 20, 30, 40) * 2) # Prints (20.0, 40.0, 60.0, 80.0)
```

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_operator_mul_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **operator ***\ (\ right\: [int](class_int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_operator_mul_int)

Multiplies each component of the **Vector4i** by the given [int](class_int.md).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_operator_sum_Vector4i"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **operator +**\ (\ right\: [Vector4i](class_vector4i.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_operator_sum_Vector4i)

Adds each component of the **Vector4i** by the components of the given **Vector4i**.

```
    print(Vector4i(10, 20, 30, 40) + Vector4i(3, 4, 5, 6)) # Prints (13, 24, 35, 46)
```

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_operator_dif_Vector4i"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **operator -**\ (\ right\: [Vector4i](class_vector4i.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_operator_dif_Vector4i)

Subtracts each component of the **Vector4i** by the components of the given **Vector4i**.

```
    print(Vector4i(10, 20, 30, 40) - Vector4i(3, 4, 5, 6)) # Prints (7, 16, 25, 34)
```

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_operator_div_Vector4i"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **operator /**\ (\ right\: [Vector4i](class_vector4i.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_operator_div_Vector4i)

Divides each component of the **Vector4i** by the components of the given **Vector4i**.

```
    print(Vector4i(10, 20, 30, 40) / Vector4i(2, 5, 3, 4)) # Prints (5, 4, 10, 10)
```

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_operator_div_float"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4](class_vector4.md) **operator /**\ (\ right\: [float](class_float.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_operator_div_float)

Divides each component of the **Vector4i** by the given [float](class_float.md).

Returns a Vector4 value due to floating-point operations.

```
    print(Vector4i(1, 2, 3, 4) / 2.5) # Prints (0.4, 0.8, 1.2, 1.6)
```

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_operator_div_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **operator /**\ (\ right\: [int](class_int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_operator_div_int)

Divides each component of the **Vector4i** by the given [int](class_int.md).

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_operator_lt_Vector4i"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **operator <**\ (\ right\: [Vector4i](class_vector4i.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_operator_lt_Vector4i)

Compares two **Vector4i** vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is less than the X value of the `right` vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors, Z values of the two vectors, and then with the W values. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_operator_lte_Vector4i"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **operator <=**\ (\ right\: [Vector4i](class_vector4i.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_operator_lte_Vector4i)

Compares two **Vector4i** vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is less than or equal to the X value of the `right` vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors, Z values of the two vectors, and then with the W values. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_operator_eq_Vector4i"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **operator ==**\ (\ right\: [Vector4i](class_vector4i.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_operator_eq_Vector4i)

Returns ``true`` if the vectors are exactly equal.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_operator_gt_Vector4i"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **operator >**\ (\ right\: [Vector4i](class_vector4i.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_operator_gt_Vector4i)

Compares two **Vector4i** vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is greater than the X value of the `right` vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors, Z values of the two vectors, and then with the W values. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_operator_gte_Vector4i"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[bool](class_bool.md) **operator >=**\ (\ right\: [Vector4i](class_vector4i.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_operator_gte_Vector4i)

Compares two **Vector4i** vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is greater than or equal to the X value of the `right` vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors, Z values of the two vectors, and then with the W values. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_operator_idx_int"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[int](class_int.md) **operator []**\ (\ index\: [int](class_int.md)\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_operator_idx_int)

Access vector components using their `index`. ``v[0]`` is equivalent to ``v.x``, ``v[1]`` is equivalent to ``v.y``, ``v[2]`` is equivalent to ``v.z``, and ``v[3]`` is equivalent to ``v.w``.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_operator_unplus"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **operator unary+**\ (\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_operator_unplus)

Returns the same value as if the ``+`` was not there. Unary ``+`` does nothing, but sometimes it can make your code more readable.

<hr class="classref-item-separator">

<a id="class_Vector4i_operator_unminus"></a>

<!-- classref-operator -->

[Vector4i](class_vector4i.md) **operator unary-**\ (\ ) [ðŸ”—](#class_Vector4i_operator_unminus)

Returns the negative value of the **Vector4i**. This is the same as writing ``Vector4i(-v.x, -v.y, -v.z, -v.w)``. This operation flips the direction of the vector while keeping the same magnitude.
